In [ ]:

%matplotlib inline

In [2]:

import numpy as np
import vibration_toolbox as vt

Vibration system objectÂ¶

This notebook will introduce the class VibSystem(), which is available in the vibration_toolbox.

As an example we will use the following 3 degree of fredom system:

System

If we look at the help for the VibSystem class we have:

Parameters
----------
M : array
    Mass matrix.
C : array
    Damping matrix.
K : array
    Stiffness matrix.
name : str, optional
    Name of the system.

So we need to get the mass, stiffness and damping matrix to create a VibSystem object (the name of the system is optional and can be used latter to help when we plot results).

For this system the kinetic energy is:

where \({\bf q(t)} = [q_0(t) \ q_1(t) \ q_2(t)]^T\) is the configuration vector. The mass matrix for this system is given by:

The potential energy is:

And the stiffness matrix is:

In this case we will consider proportional damping: \(C = \alpha M + \beta K\).

Let’s consider the following values for our system:

In [3]:

m0, m1, m2 = (1, 1, 1)
k0, k1, k2 = (1600, 1600, 1600)
alpha, beta = 1e-3, 1e-3

Now we use numpy to create our matrices:

In [4]:

M = np.array([[m0, 0, 0],
              [0, m1, 0],
              [0, 0, m2]])
K = np.array([[k0+k1, -k1,   0],
              [-k1, k1+k2, -k2],
              [0,     -k2,  k2]])
C = alpha*M + beta*K

Now we have everything needed to create a vibration system object:

In [5]:

sys = vt.VibSystem(M, C, K, name='3 dof system')

Now, if we type ``sys.`` and press tab we can see the system’s attributes and methods that are available.

As an example we can get the natural frequencies:

In [9]:

sys.wn

Out[9]:

array([  2.83322453,   7.93851871,  11.47149191])

Or the damped natural frequencies:

In [10]:

sys.wd

Out[10]:

array([  2.83220788,   7.9162503 ,  11.40422301])

M, C and K can be changed and the system will be updated:

In [21]:

sys.C = 10*C
sys.wd

Out[21]:

array([  2.82190789,   7.68746931,  10.70033077])
